The tobacco manufacturers contend that the increase was too great.

Recently, the six State Ministers for Agriculture were with me in Adelaide at a meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council. I arranged for growers' representatives to meet us there, and we also met the manufacturers' representatives and had certain discussions. A few weeks later we had a conference with growers in Canberra and met the manufacturers again. The dissatisfaction expressed at these meetings prompted the Government to take action and a committee was appointed to investigate unsold tobacco or tobacco for which no bid had been made. That committee is making its investigations at the present time. Its members are technical officers of the manufacturers, officers of the State departments concerned, officers of the Department of Primary Industry and the Department of Customs and Excise and the growers' own assessor.

It is too soon to assess the results of the inquiry, but I can say that the unanimous decision of the committee - which includes the growers' assessor - is that over 33 per cent, of the leaf can be classed as unusable.

talk.start.para: - The percentage is even higher than that.
- In certain instances it is up to 50 per cent. Production has increased greatly, but perhaps not enough care has been taken in respect of quality or leaf has been grown on unsuitable soil.
- That is not disputed, but what is going to happen about it?

- The honorable member has made the point the manufacturers are paying a lower average price. If a sale is made what can the Commonwealth Government do about it? We are not a socialist government which dictates that a certain price has to be paid.
- You are not even a humane government!
- That is another matter. Who is going to force anybody to pay a certain price if it does not suit him to pay that price?
- I am not asking for that.
- The honorable member did suggest it.
- I want to know what the Government is going to do.

- The honorable member has been attending meetings and speaking at them without knowing the facts whereas the Government has been working. The honorable member for Indi (Mr. Holten) knows this better than anybody else because he has kept in touch with me almost daily. On the humane side he has induced the Rural Finance Corporation to send its representative to see what financial help can be given. That officer is at present working in the district and has been achieving results as far as he, as a representative of the corporation, can get results.
- I do not care who gets the results as long as results are obtained.

- The point I make is that it is still too early to know the results of the investigation that is at present taking place. The honorable member asked about the report of the meeting. The meeting that he attended was not called by an official organization in the industry.
- That may be so, but there were 600 growers present.

- I am informed that the hall in which the meeting was held would not hold more than 300, but that is another matter. I am not arguing about it. I will concede that there was a big representation of the industry present.

speech.para: I have not received the report of that meeting, but a delegation did meet the Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) yesterday afternoon. I was busy with legislation at the time, but I did meet the delegation afterwards. In fact, three Ministers met it. As a result, officers of my department have been allotted to assist the delegation to make its case. That is where the matter stands at present. We are awaiting the report of the committee. There is no aspect of this matter with which we are not in constant touch.

Wherever the fault lies, and there is fault - whether it is that the growers have been led into producing in excess of their capabilities, or whether they have been taking too much for granted - that does not help the fellow who is at present in trouble. Although it is not the responsibility of the Government, that does not exclude the Government from accepting some responsibility in the issue. The Government did fix the figure of 43 per cent. The manufacturers complained that it was too high. I have made a statement to the effect that the Government will not retreat from that position. If there is any suggestion that to do so would weaken the position of the growers, I assure honorable members that the Government will not retreat from the decision it has made.

talk.start.para: - The trouble is that the percentage is inadequate to absorb the amount of leaf that is available.

- On evidence submitted to the committee, the position seems to be that if the manufacturers bought all the usable leaf they would be hard put to make up the 43 per cent. The 43 per cent, allows for a 10 per cent, rejection overall. I understand that from the mathematical stand-point the percentage works out at 47.78 per cent. In order to meet the 47.78 per cent, standard, there would have to be a 100 per cent, compulsory sale, but no one can suggest that there should not be some rejection allowed.
- A 10 per cent, rejection would be satisfactory.

-I suggest, therefore, that the Commonwealth fixation of the percentage is satisfactory. The Government has intimated to manufacturers that it does not expect them to buy unusable leaf, but it does expect them to buy up usable leaf.
- Order! The Minister's time has expired.

. - I have listened to the debate initiated by the honorable member for Wannon (Mr. Malcolm Fraser), who was followedbythehonorablememberfor Lalor (Mr. Pollard). The honorable member for Wannon posed the proposition that the only resource the growers had was to approach the Government. On the other hand, the honorable member for Lalor has said that as a Federal Minister vested with war-time powers he had been able to deal with such a situation. I have risen merely to point out that wool-growers have in their hands a means of redress if they use the powers available to them. I cite a case in point.

speech.para: A move was made in the city of Newcastle for the decentralization of wool selling by a company which found its main strength in the north and north-west of New South Wales. The company was boycotted. The two men who led the fight in the graziers' organization and the wool council were Phillip Wright, of Wallamumbi, Armidale, and Colonel White, of Bald Blair. The names of those two men are honoured because of their fight. They won out as the result of getting the support of their organizations, and to-day practically every wool firm of any standing has its own warehouses in Newcastle. The objection of the people in the north to having their wool carried 100 miles unnecessarily to Sydney has been fully substantiated by the results of very successful sales at Newcastle. I suggest that the honorable member for Wannon say to his friends, " Go thou and do likewise ".
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration, upon notice -

item.para: How many persons born in Asia were granted permanent residence in Australia in each year since 1940?
How many persons born in Asia entered Australia in each year since 1940 and remained for one year or more?
What are the categories of persons born in Asia who may be admitted to, or allowed to remain in, Australia as permanent residents?
How many persons in each of these categories have been admitted, oi allowed to remain, in each year since 1940?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: Over the period 1940 to 1952 policy provided only that certain non-European children born abroad of fathers permanently domiciled in Australia would be admitted for permanent residence. The total number of such children admitted over the period did not exceed ten. Over the period 1952 to 1958 policy provided that certain non-Europeans who were engaged in local or overseas trade, who had been lawfully admitted, who were abiding by the conditions of their continued stay, and who had been here for at least fifteen years, could be admitted to remain without extension of their Certificates of Exemption. A ruling of the High Court established that this meant, in effect, that such persons had been granted permanent residence. The number of Asians who acquired permanent residence in this way is as follows:- 1952, 10; 1953, 51; 1954, 75; 1955, 18; 1956, 19; 1957, 4; total, 177. In late 1957 the Government agreed that any lawfully admitted non-European who had resided in Australia for at least fifteen years, who was of good character, who had abided by the conditions of his entry and continued stay, who had an acceptable knowledge of English and who had taken a part in normal Australian life could be granted permanent residence. The number of Asians who have acquired permanent residence in accordance with these provisions is as follows: - 1958, 142; 1959, 183; 1960, 187; total, 512. In 1960 it was decided that as policy had been changed to provide that the non-European spouses and minor unmarried children of British subjects (including Australian citizens) lawfully resident in Australia and not under immigration restriction, could be admitted for permanent residence, the temporary entry permits of those admitted under previous rules would be allowed to lapse and they would be regarded as having been granted permanent residence. Similar approval was given in respect of aged dependants, while it was also provided that the non-European fiancees of these sponsors would be entitled to permanent residence on marriage instead of being kept under immigration restriction as provided in earlier rules. As no formalities are associated with the grant of permanent residence in these cases, no specific figures have been maintained of those who, having entered under immigration restriction have acquired or who have become entitled to permanent residence upon the expiration of their temporary entry permits. To the end of 1960, the following had been admitted: - Spouses and aged dependants, 766; children, 165; fiancées. 165; total, 1,096.

Figures in the form requested by the honorable member are not available for it has not been the practice to record arrivals by place of birth nor to maintain records of just how long a person who enters remains in Australia. When a person arrives he is asked to indicate whether he intends to remain here for one year or longer and certain statistics are maintained on this basis. However, as almost invariably the ultimate figures show that on this basis of record many more visitors depart than ever arrive only the " net migration " figures taken over time can give anything like an accurate picture. With this in mind, the following are the estimated " net migration " figures in respect of Asian entry over the period concerned: -

The " net migration " figures for the period 1950 to 1960 reflect very largely the non-European private student project. As at the 30th June, 1960, there were 7,918 non-European private students studying in Australia.

Any Asian lawfully admitted into Australia for temporary residence who resides here for fifteen years, who is of good character, who has a" working knowledge of the English language, end who has taken part in normal Australian life, may apply for and be granted permanent residence. Any Asian fiancé or fiancee of a British subject (lawfully resident in Australia and not under immigration restriction), is admitted under restriction for an initial period of three months but is granted permanent residence when the marriage takes place. Any Asian spouse of a British subject (lawfully resident in Australia and not under immigration restriction) who was admitted at a time when such spouses were not granted permanent residence may now be granted permanent residence when any certificate of exemption or temporary entry permit now held expires. The only Asians eligible for entry for permanent residence are the spouses and minor unmarried children and aged dependent parents of British subjects who are lawfully resident in Australia and who themselves are not under immigration restriction.
To the extent to which the information requested is available it is given in the answer to the first part of the honorable member's question.
